results.content:
Started with this course in the latter part of 2017 and  I haven't stopped installing laravel on every project I've touched since. Coming prior to this course I was all about Python and simple MVC of PHP. Laravel taught in this course, gives you the ability to understand it fully to the degree it's basically understandable with this amazing instructor. 

I know there's more out there, I've actually purchased many different laravel courses on this site so I can dive deeper into it all, however, the old saying goes, once you learn one language, it'll be easier to grasp another, but I love to see how everyone (different instructors) interprets it and applies it to their day to day processes. 

Thank you for such an amazing course though Eduonix. I would love to see more coming from you on how to upgrade each of these projects from 5.5->5.6->5.7->5.8 also an amazing series explaining why they changed what they changed in the cores and how it affected each project if it did. I know of a few getClientSize() is now getSize() but I have to say, this course basically opened up MANY doors for myself personally.

results.content: What I really like about this project is that it allows you to really understand the fundamentals of Laravel, and the conventions of Laravel in it's simplest form. You may be using different "names" when it comes to the project you are working on, but the concepts, and fundamentals of how to set up your backend are the same, and its nice going through and applying those concepts to what you may be doing at an actual job, or even as something you are working on in your spare time.

results.content:
Even though Laravel 5.7 is out, I created a project with laravel 5.4 because that was used in this course. I kept getting erros when running anything with npm run. I found I needed to add dist before bin in package.json, but still didn't got errors. Did research and added node before node_modules, then got different error, Invalid configuration object. Webpack has been initialised using a configuration object that does not match the API schema.
 - configuration.output.path: The provided value "public" is not an absolute path! Reinstalled node and npm, but still no luck. Now I am in the process of creating a new project with laravel 5.7 and see how that goes.
results.content_html:
Even though Laravel 5.7 is out, I created a project with laravel 5.4 because that was used in this course. I kept getting erros when running anything with npm run. I found I needed to add dist before bin in package.json, but still didn't got errors. Did research and added node before node_modules, then got different error, Invalid configuration object. Webpack has been initialised using a configuration object that does not match the API schema.
- configuration.output.path: The provided value "public" is not an absolute path! Reinstalled node and npm, but still no luck. Now I am in the process of creating a new project with laravel 5.7 and see how that goes.

results.content:
I took this course for the lessons that come at the end. The first four chapters were adequately explained but their explanation can be found elsewhere on the internet for free.

Explaining the CMS chapter was chaotic specially in its last videos. Even though it is meant to be quick but it would be beneficial to see explain how the model is working.

Videos that come later on are poor. For example in video #48 you will still be redirected to /home (if you type /home) even if you're not logged in. The instructor tries not to show this but it is done in a wrong fashion and needs ironing.

In video 49, at 8:07, the login appears inside the inbox, same for the register at 11:09 and in the send message(/create). In my opinion stuff like this shouldn't appear in well prepared courses.

Also in the message system, one should be able to read their own messages only, whereas the implementation here allows accessing all messages by tampering with the URL.

Section 9 is not really explained; he just shows work. He doesn't really explain vue and axios.

Section 10 is unorganized and the instructor doens't clarify what he is doing.
results.content_html:
I took this course for the lessons that come at the end. The first four chapters were adequately explained but their explanation can be found elsewhere on the internet for free.

Explaining the CMS chapter was chaotic specially in its last videos. Even though it is meant to be quick but it would be beneficial to see explain how the model is working.

Videos that come later on are poor. For example in video #48 you will still be redirected to /home (if you type /home) even if you're not logged in. The instructor tries not to show this but it is done in a wrong fashion and needs ironing.

In video 49, at 8:07, the login appears inside the inbox, same for the register at 11:09 and in the send message(/create). In my opinion stuff like this shouldn't appear in well prepared courses.

Also in the message system, one should be able to read their own messages only, whereas the implementation here allows accessing all messages by tampering with the URL.

Section 9 is not really explained; he just shows work. He doesn't really explain vue and axios.

Section 10 is unorganized and the instructor doens't clarify what he is doing.

results.content:
My biggest gripe is that the course is too  basic. Yes, there are 10 projects, but by the time you actually finish setup and get into one, it's abandoned for another project. There are instructions without explanations of what exactly we are doing, or trying to achieve.
For example, what is an AppServiceProvider? We went into the file 9 times to change something, but what is a service provider's purpose? A couple of sentences would've helped actually teach Laravel's concepts, rather than just how to install it, run some CLI commands, and fill up a single controller&model.
On the positive side, you are introduced to some additions (like Backpack or OctoberCMS) that can be used in future projects, but that, too, is done only on a rudimentary level. You'd actually need to learn most of Laravel by yourself.

results.content:
It was a pretty interesting course and it’s good for me because I was seeking the fundamentals of Laravel (I have some years of CodeIgniter and CakePHP development and I wanted to start with Laravel). What I think it could be improved is more intermediate/advanced strategies framework-wise. For instance, the teacher was really trying hard to find different content for the different kinds of projects, which is awesome, but he did differentiate stuff like front end libraries and databases, and forgot the main reason of the course: LARAVEL - and kept repeating basically the same stuff: CRUD CRUD CRUD CRUD CRUD...

He could’ve started with a simple CRUD and simple Auth (as he did), and, later on into the course, to be different, he could improved the login system to act different for different permission groups. Also he could’ve made an app with at least a hasAndBelongsToMany relationship to teach how to handle stuff in the models, and how to deal with the front end when you get back the results. Another app would be one with a more complex business logic to show the ideal place to put them (and they should not go in the controller and be repetitive like there were 2 equal file upload logics in 2 different controllers in the Gallery project).

That’s my 2 cents, but overall it’s a nice beginners course.

results.content:
This course is out of date.  

It seems like a very well done course, but the information is hard to follow because what I get when I do what the instructor did is not the same.  Thus far I've spent about 3 hours just googling around and fixing random things like the fact that my navbar (when following the given steps) doesn't show up styled.  It's more frustrating than it's worth. 

I probably should have checked the "last updated" date before I bought this. I kinda wish they'd just stop selling courses that are this out of date. 

Anyway, i was really excited for this one, so I'm not going to return it yet. I'll come back to it after I finish my initial laravel setup training elsewhere, because the projects seem interesting.  I'll update this review if the later projects are better and require less googling.

results.content:
I have only done the first project, but I'm massively disappointed with this course. I've followed a few of Brad's tutorials on youtube and I liked his style, so I tried this Udemy course. Unfortunately there are a few big problems with the course:

1) It doesn't use the latest version of laravel and, crucially, it doesn't provide any guidance on how to ensure you install the version of laravel and bootstrap etc that Brad uses. So you can end up with Laravel 5.8 and Bootstrap 4, which don't work in the same way as Laravel 5.4 and Bootstrap 3. I've done other Udemy courses that are a few years old, but they're kept up-to-date, or the required config info is provided.

2) Brad uses Windows and doesn't provide any alternate instructions on how to do things with a Mac. This is really annoying and surprising as at least as many people will be using a Mac as a PC.

3) Brad doesn't answer questions, and the Eduonix TAs aren't up to scratch. Maybe they're not being paid very much, but just directing people to stackoverflow questions isn't helpful. 

4) He uses xammpp with phpmyadmin. Why not use the laravel homestead vagrant environment and MySQL workbench, which aren't that hard to set up, and are more likely to be used in a commecial situation? Brad has a really good intro video on MySQL server and Workbench on youtube. It would be better if he incorporated it into this course.

5) I don't know if this improves on later projects, but Brad gives very little in the way of explanation of how things work or the concepts behind them. I've read this criticism of his teaching style in reviews and I've found it to be true. Yes, you can consult the docs for each new thing, but you shouldn't have to. It's not very hard to video yourself coding a project you've already created, it is hard to clearly explain how each bit works as you're doing it, and this doesn't happen.

I've done other web dev Udemy courses by people like Colt Steele, Stephen Grider and Jonas Scmedtmann, and they all update their courses regularly and provide detailed conceptual explanations of how the code works. I really hoped this course would be similar, but it's not.

I'll try the next project, but if it doesn't improve, this course will have been a waste of money for me.
